articles.headline: Out From India’s Alleys, Gold Loans Gain Respect
articles.snippet: A fast-growing segment of the lending industry serves the many Indians who lack paperwork to prove their income or collateral other than gold jewelry.
articles.abstract: A fast-growing segment of the lending industry serves the many Indians who lack paperwork to prove their income or collateral other than gold jewelry.
articles.lead_paragraph: KOCHI, India  Indians own more gold than the citizens of any other country. They use the glittering metal as ornaments to flaunt family wealth, as a source of retirement savings and as insurance against calamities.

articles.headline: Creeping Up to 5 Digits Yet Again
articles.snippet: Crossing 10,000 means clearing a symbolic hurdle, even if it’s one the Dow industrial average first vaulted a decade ago.
articles.abstract: Crossing 10,000 means clearing a symbolic hurdle, even if it’s one the Dow industrial average first vaulted a decade ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is only a number  the stock market equivalent of an appliance chain’s millionth customer, or the gazillionth hamburger served at McDonald’s.

articles.headline: Europe’s Socialists Suffering Even in Downturn
articles.snippet: Europe’s Socialist parties and their left-wing cousins have not been able to take advantage of the right’s failures.
articles.abstract: Europe’s Socialist parties and their left-wing cousins have not been able to take advantage of the right’s failures.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS  A specter is haunting Europe  the specter of Socialism’s slow collapse.

articles.headline: From Science, Plenty of Cows but Little Profit
articles.snippet: New technology allowing farmers to produce more female calves comes as the industry is struggling to cut output.
articles.abstract: New technology allowing farmers to produce more female calves comes as the industry is struggling to cut output.
articles.lead_paragraph: HANFORD, Calif.  Three years ago, a technological breakthrough gave dairy farmers the chance to bend a basic rule of nature: no longer would their cows have to give birth to equal numbers of female and male offspring. Instead, using a high-technology method to sort the sperm of dairy bulls, they could produce mostly female calves to be raised into profitable milk producers.

articles.headline: Big Merger Deals Signal Restored Confidence
articles.snippet: A flurry of mergers in the last month suggest that corporate America may have a more optimistic outlook on the economy than some people thought.
articles.abstract: A flurry of mergers in the last month suggest that corporate America may have a more optimistic outlook on the economy than some people thought.
articles.lead_paragraph: The corner office is getting a bit more bullish about the economy.

articles.headline: A Nuclear Debate: Is Iran Designing Warheads?
articles.snippet: A dispute among American, European and Israeli spies about Iran’s advanced weapons work has huge political consequences.
articles.abstract: A dispute among American, European and Israeli spies about Iran’s advanced weapons work has huge political consequences.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article is by William J. Broad, Mark Mazzetti and David E. Sanger.
articles.byline: By William J. Broad, Mark Mazzetti and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Climate Bill Splits Exelon and U.S. Chamber
articles.snippet: Exelon, the largest U.S. operator of nuclear plants, became the third major utility to cancel its membership in the Chamber of Commerce because of differences over climate policies.
articles.abstract: Exelon, the largest U.S. operator of nuclear plants, became the third major utility to cancel its membership in the Chamber of Commerce because of differences over climate policies.
articles.lead_paragraph: Exelon, one of the country’s largest utilities, said Monday that it would quit the United States Chamber of Commerce because of that group’s stance on climate change. It was the latest in a string of companies to do so, perhaps a harbinger of how intense the fight over global warming legislation could become.
articles.byline: By Clifford Krauss and Kate Galbraith

articles.headline: Banks to Prepay Assessments to Rescue F.D.I.C.
articles.snippet: Federal officials proposed a $45 billion plan financed by the industry to rescue the ailing insurance fund that protects bank depositors.
articles.abstract: Federal officials proposed a $45 billion plan financed by the industry to rescue the ailing insurance fund that protects bank depositors.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Acknowledging that they had greatly underestimated the problems plaguing the nation’s banks, federal officials on Tuesday proposed a $45 billion plan financed by the industry to rescue the ailing insurance fund that protects bank depositors.
